Introduction

A signal is is a function of independent variables. We only deal with signals that are functions of time.

A system generate signals or modify them. A signal processes input signals and generates output signals.

Review: Complex Number

Z=a+jbZ=a+jbZ=a+jb

Euler's formula: ejθ=cos⁡θ+jsin⁡θe^{j\theta}=\cos\theta + j\sin\thetaejθ=cosθ+jsinθ

Complex Conjugate: Z∗=a−jbZ^*=a-jbZ∗=a−jb

Classification of Signals

C.T. vs D.T.

Continuous-Time (C.T.) Signal is defined over a continuous range of time. It is denoted as x(t)x(t)x(t) vs ttt.

Discrete-Time (D.T.) Signal is a sequence of numbers. The signal is specified at discrete values of time. It is denoted as x[n]x[n]x[n] vs nnn.

A C.T. signal can be sampled to create a D.T. signal. If we sample x(t)x(t)x(t) with a sampling interval of TTT:

  • x(nT)x(nT)x(nT) is xxx at nTnTnT
  • x[n]=x(nT)x[n]=x(nT)x[n]=x(nT)

Analog vs Digital

Analog Signal's dependent variable can take any value in a continuous range.

Digital Signal's dependent variable can only take discrete values in a range.

Note that C.T.≢AnalogC.T. \not\equiv AnalogC.T.​≡Analog and D.T.≢DigitalD.T.\not\equiv DigitalD.T.​≡Digital. We could have

  • analog, continuous time
  • digital, continuous time
  • analog, discrete time
  • digital, discrete time

Periodic vs Aperiodic

x(t)x(t)x(t) is periodic if ∃ T0∈R+:x(t)=x(t+T0)\exists\ T_0\in \mathbb{R}^+:x(t)=x(t+T_0)∃ T0​∈R+:x(t)=x(t+T0​). The fundamental period of x(t)x(t)x(t) is defined as the smallest value of T0T_0T0​ that satisfies periodicity condition. Note that a periodic signal mast be continuous in range (−∞,∞)(-\infty,\infty)(−∞,∞).

A periodic signal has the property: area under curve over any segment of duration T0T_0T0​ will be constant.

∫aa+T0x(t)dt=∫bb+T0x(t)dt\int_a^{a+T_0} x(t)\mathrm{dt}=\int_b^{b+T_0} x(t)\mathrm{dt} ∫aa+T0​​x(t)dt=∫bb+T0​​x(t)dt

We denote it as ∫T0x(t)dt\displaystyle \int_{T_0} x(t)\mathrm{dt}∫T0​​x(t)dt

An aperiodic signal is not periodic.

Energy and Power Signals:

Signal Energy is a quantity to determine the size (strength) of a signal:

Ex=∫−∞∞∣x(t)∣2dtE_x=\int_{-\infty}^\infty |x(t)|^2\mathrm{dt} Ex​=∫−∞∞​∣x(t)∣2dt

where x(t)x(t)x(t) is a complex signal of the form x(t)=a+jbx(t)=a+jbx(t)=a+jb.

Energy Signal is a signal with finite energy. Note that ExE_xEx​ does not converge if lim⁡t→∞x(t)≠0\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}x(t)\neq0t→∞lim​x(t)​=0.

Ex={∫−∞∞∣x(t)∣2dt(C.T.)∑∣x[n]∣2(D.T.)E_x= \begin{cases} \displaystyle \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x(t)|^2\mathrm dt&\textrm{(C.T.)}\\\\ \displaystyle \sum|x[n]|^2 &\textrm{(D.T.)} \end{cases} Ex​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​∫−∞∞​∣x(t)∣2dt∑∣x[n]∣2​(C.T.)(D.T.)​

Signal Power is another measure of signal size, especially when lim⁡t→∞x(t)≠0\displaystyle\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}x(t)\neq0t→∞lim​x(t)​=0.

Px={lim⁡T→∞1T∫−T/2T/2∣x(t)∣2dt(C.T.)lim⁡N→∞12N+1∑n=−NN∣x[n]∣2(D.T.)P_x= \begin{cases} \displaystyle \lim_{T\rightarrow\infty} \frac{1}{T}\int_{-T/2}^{T/2} |x(t)|^2 \mathrm{dt} &\textrm{(C.T.)}\\\\ \displaystyle \lim_{N\rightarrow\infty} \frac{1}{2N+1}\sum_{n=-N}^{N} |x[n]|^2 &\textrm{(D.T.)} \end{cases} Px​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​T→∞lim​T1​∫−T/2T/2​∣x(t)∣2dtN→∞lim​2N+11​n=−N∑N​∣x[n]∣2​(C.T.)(D.T.)​

Note that:

  1. An energy signal has zero power.
  2. A signal with finite power has infinite energy.

This means that a signal cannot be both power and energy signal, but can be neither:

RMS value of a signal is the square root of its power (PxP_xPx​).

Deterministic vs Stochastic

Deterministic Signals are predictable and can be described by equations.

Random or Stochastic Signals are not predictable.

Causal, Noncausal, Anticausal Signals

Causal Signals: x(t)=0 ∀ t<0x(t)=0\ \forall\ t<0x(t)=0 ∀ t<0.

Noncausal Signals: if signal starts before t=0t=0t=0

Anticausal Signals: x(t)=0 ∀ t≥0x(t)=0\ \forall\ t\ge 0x(t)=0 ∀ t≥0

Signal Operations

Time Shifting

For a C.T. signal, to shift x(t)x(t)x(t) to the right by TTT to a new signal φ(t)\varphi(t)φ(t), we have the relation x(t−T)=φ(t)x(t-T)=\varphi(t)x(t−T)=φ(t).

A time shifting of a signal by TTT is done by replacing ttt with t−Tt-Tt−T:

{T>0→signal is delayed (shifts to right)T<0→signal is advanced (shifts to left)\begin{cases} T>0 &\rightarrow\quad \textrm{signal is delayed (shifts to right)}\\ T<0 &\rightarrow\quad \textrm{signal is advanced (shifts to left)} \end{cases}{T>0T<0​→signal is delayed (shifts to right)→signal is advanced (shifts to left)​

Similarly, to shift a D.T. signal x[n]x[n]x[n] by MMM unit, we replace nnn with n−Mn-Mn−M:

{M>0→signal is delayed (shifts to right)M<0→signal is advanced (shifts to left)\begin{cases} M>0 &\rightarrow\quad \textrm{signal is delayed (shifts to right)}\\ M<0 &\rightarrow\quad \textrm{signal is advanced (shifts to left)} \end{cases}{M>0M<0​→signal is delayed (shifts to right)→signal is advanced (shifts to left)​

Time Scaling

If a C.T. signal x(t)x(t)x(t) is compressed in time by a factor of aaa (a>1a>1a>1), the resulting compressed signal φ(t)=x(at)\varphi(t)=x(at)φ(t)=x(at).

C.T. signal expansion by a factor of a>1a>1a>1 is φ(t)=x(t/a)\varphi(t)=x(t/a)φ(t)=x(t/a).

For a D.T. signal, down sampling refers to signal compression. When compression occurs by a factor M>0M>0M>0, xd[n]=x[Mn]x_d[n]=x[Mn]xd​[n]=x[Mn]

D.T. signal upsampling occurs when expansion occurs. Interpolation is required to fill in the gaps between original signals.

xe[n]={x[n/L](if n=0±L,±2L,… )0(otherwise)x_e[n]= \begin{cases} x[n/L] &(\textrm{if }n=0\pm L, \pm 2L, \dots)\\ 0 & (\textrm{otherwise}) \end{cases} xe​[n]={x[n/L]0​(if n=0±L,±2L,…)(otherwise)​

In C.T. signals, compression doesn't cause information loss, but in D.T. signals, downsampling causes information loss.

Time Reversal

Time Reversal: reflection of x(t)x(t)x(t) about vertical axis.

{φ(t)=x(−t)(C.T.)xr[n]=x[−n](D.T.)\begin{cases} \varphi(t)=x(-t) &\textrm{(C.T.)}\\ x_r[n] = x[-n] &\textrm{(D.T.)} \end{cases}{φ(t)=x(−t)xr​[n]=x[−n]​(C.T.)(D.T.)​

Useful Signal Models

Unit Step Signal

Unit Step Signal, aka Heaviside Signal, is a signal that has the form

u(t)={1t≥00t<0(C.T.)u(t)=\begin{cases} 1 & t\ge 0 \\ 0 & t < 0\end{cases}\quad\textrm{(C.T.)} u(t)={10​t≥0t<0​(C.T.)

u[n]={1n≥00n<0(D.T.)u[n]=\begin{cases}1 & n\ge 0 \\ 0 & n < 0\end{cases}\quad\textrm{(D.T.)} u[n]={10​n≥0n<0​(D.T.)

For example,

  • x(t)(u(t)−u(t−2))\displaystyle x(t)\left(u(t)-u(t-2)\right)x(t)(u(t)−u(t−2)) captures x(t)x(t)x(t) in interval t∈[0,2)t\in[0,2)t∈[0,2)
  • x[n](u[n]−u[n−4])x[n](u[n]-u[n-4])x[n](u[n]−u[n−4]) captures u[n]u[n]u[n] in range n∈[0,4),n∈Zn\in[0,4),n\in\mathbb{Z}n∈[0,4),n∈Z

Unit Impulse

For C.T. signal, we have Dirac delta function:

{δ(t)=0∀ t≠0∫−∞∞δ(t)=1(wtf)\begin{cases} \delta(t)=0 &\forall\ t\neq 0\\ \displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\delta(t)=1 & \textrm{(wtf)} \end{cases} ⎩⎨⎧​δ(t)=0∫−∞∞​δ(t)=1​∀ t​=0(wtf)​

How does this work???

  • Imagine width of the signal is ϵ→0\epsilon\rightarrow 0ϵ→0 (infinitesimally small)
  • Imagine the height of the signal is 1/ϵ→∞1/\epsilon\rightarrow\infty1/ϵ→∞ (infinitesimally tall)
  • The overall area is unity (111)

In practice, an ideal impulse function cannot be generated; we can approximate it.

For D.T. signal, we have Kronecker delta function

δ[n]={1n=00n≠0\delta[n]=\begin{cases}1&n=0\\0&n\neq 0\end{cases} δ[n]={10​n=0n​=0​

Multiplication of a signal by an impulse:

Φ(t)δ(t)=Φ(0)δ(t)\Phi(t)\delta(t)=\Phi(0)\delta(t) Φ(t)δ(t)=Φ(0)δ(t)

Φ(t)δ(t−T)=Φ(T)δ(t−T)\Phi(t)\delta(t-T)=\Phi(T)\delta(t-T) Φ(t)δ(t−T)=Φ(T)δ(t−T)

Sampling or Sifting Property of unit impulse

∫−∞∞Φ(t)δ(t−T)dt=Φ(T)∫−∞∞δ(t−T)dt=Φ(T)\int_{-\infty}^\infty\Phi(t)\delta(t-T)\mathrm{dt}=\Phi(T)\int_{-\infty}^\infty\delta(t-T)\mathrm{dt}=\Phi(T) ∫−∞∞​Φ(t)δ(t−T)dt=Φ(T)∫−∞∞​δ(t−T)dt=Φ(T)

Relating Unit Impulse and Unit Signal

Surprise, surprise.

δ(t)=ddtu(t)=δ(t)\delta(t)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{dt}} u(t)=\delta(t) δ(t)=dtd​u(t)=δ(t)

Exponential Functions

For C.T. signal, este^{st}est, where s=σ+jωs=\sigma+j\omegas=σ+jω.

est=eσt(cos⁡(ωt)+jsin⁡(ωt))e^{st}=e^{\sigma t}(\cos(\omega t)+j\sin(\omega t)) est=eσt(cos(ωt)+jsin(ωt))

For D.T. signal, esn=γne^{sn}=\gamma^nesn=γn, where s=σ+jω∧es=γs=\sigma+j\omega\wedge e^s=\gammas=σ+jω∧es=γ.

γ=eσejω\gamma=e^{\sigma}e^{j\omega} γ=eσejω

∣γ∣=∣eσ∣since∣ejω∣=1|\gamma|=|e^\sigma|\quad\textrm{since}\quad|e^{j\omega}|=1 ∣γ∣=∣eσ∣since∣ejω∣=1

We have:

{σ=0⇒∣γ∣=∣eσ∣=1σ<0⇒∣γ∣=∣eσ∣<1σ>0⇒∣γ∣=∣eσ∣>1\begin{cases} \sigma=0&\Rightarrow \quad|\gamma|=|e^\sigma|=1\\ \sigma<0&\Rightarrow \quad|\gamma|=|e^\sigma|<1\\ \sigma>0&\Rightarrow \quad|\gamma|=|e^\sigma|>1 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​σ=0σ<0σ>0​⇒∣γ∣=∣eσ∣=1⇒∣γ∣=∣eσ∣<1⇒∣γ∣=∣eσ∣>1​

System Classifications

C.T vs D.T., Analog vs Digital

C.T. Systems have C.T. input and output signals.

D.T. Systems have D.T. input and output signals.

Analog systems have analog input and output signals.

Digital systems have digital input and output signals.

Time-Invariant vs Time-Varying Systems

Time-invariant or constant parameter system: its parameters don't change with time. If the input is delayed by TTT, the output is the same but delayed by TTT.

{x(t)⇒systemy(t)⇔x(t−T)⇒systemy(t−T)x[n]⇒systemy[n]⇔x[n−m]⇒systemy[n−m]\begin{cases} x(t)\xRightarrow{\textrm{system}}y(t)\Leftrightarrow x(t-T)\xRightarrow{\textrm{system}}y(t-T)\\ x[n]\xRightarrow{\textrm{system}}y[n]\Leftrightarrow x[n-m]\xRightarrow{\textrm{system}}y[n-m] \end{cases} {x(t)system​y(t)⇔x(t−T)system​y(t−T)x[n]system​y[n]⇔x[n−m]system​y[n−m]​

Time-varying systems are not time-invariant.

Procedure to test time variance:

  1. Delay input, change all ttt inside x(… )x(\dots)x(…) to t+δt+\deltat+δ, and obtain y1(t)y_1(t)y1​(t).
  2. Delay output, change all ttt to t+δt+\deltat+δ, and obtain y2(t)y_2(t)y2​(t)
  3. Compare, y1=y2⇒y_1=y_2\Rightarrowy1​=y2​⇒ Time Invariant

Memoryless vs Dynamic (with memory) Systems

Memoryless Systems: the output at ttt only depends on the input at time ttt.

System with Memory: the output depends on past inputs.

System with finite memory of TTT seconds: output are determined by the inputs in last TTT seconds.

System with infinite memory: output at time ttt depends on inputs over the past (−∞,t](-\infty,t](−∞,t]

Examples:

  • y(t)=(t−1)x(t)y(t)=(t-1)x(t)y(t)=(t−1)x(t) is memoryless
  • y(t)=(t−1)x(t)+x(t−3)y(t)=(t-1)x(t) + x(t-3)y(t)=(t−1)x(t)+x(t−3) has finite memory of 333s
  • y[n]=y[n−1]+x[n]=∑k=−∞nx[k]\displaystyle y[n]=y[n-1]+x[n]=\sum_{k=-\infty}^n x[k]y[n]=y[n−1]+x[n]=k=−∞∑n​x[k] (accumulator function) has infinite memory

Causal vs Noncausal Systems

Causal systems: output only depends on past and present input (outputs cannot start before the inputs start). E.g. y(t)=x(t)+x(t−2)y(t)=x(t)+x(t-2)y(t)=x(t)+x(t−2) and y(t)=x(t)sin⁡(t+2)y(t)=x(t)\sin(t+2)y(t)=x(t)sin(t+2) are causal because they only depends on input at time ttt.

Noncausal systems: output starts before the input starts. e.g. y(t)=x(t+1)−x(t)y(t)=x(t+1)-x(t)y(t)=x(t+1)−x(t) and y[n]=x[n+3]+x[n−3]y[n]=x[n+3]+x[n-3]y[n]=x[n+3]+x[n−3] are noncausal.

Ignore the examples, just check the graph of output y(t)y(t)y(t) and input x(t)x(t)x(t) and see who started first.

Noncausal systems are not realizable in real time but can be useful for recorded data, e.g. a moving average system.

Invertible vs Noninvertible Systems

A system is invertible if its input can be obtained (recovered) from its output. (There should be one-to-one mapping between input and output.)

x(t)⇒Sy(t)⇒Six(t)x(t)\xRightarrow{S}y(t)\xRightarrow{S_i}x(t) x(t)S​y(t)Si​​x(t)

Non-invertible systems do not have one-to-one mapping between input and output, e.g. y(t)=x2(t)y(t)=x^2(t)y(t)=x2(t) gets rid of the negative sign and is non-invertible.

Stable vs Unstable Systems

A system is Bounded Input/Bounded Output (BIBO) stable if and only if every bounded input results in bounded output.

{C.T.:∣x(t)∣≤Mx<∞⇒∣y(t)∣≤My<∞D.T.:∣x[n]∣≤Mx<∞⇒∣y[t]∣≤My<∞\begin{cases} \textrm{C.T.:}&|x(t)|\le M_x <\infty &\Rightarrow\quad |y(t)|\le M_y< \infty\\ \textrm{D.T.:}&|x[n]|\le M_x <\infty &\Rightarrow\quad |y[t]|\le M_y< \infty \end{cases} {C.T.:D.T.:​∣x(t)∣≤Mx​<∞∣x[n]∣≤Mx​<∞​⇒∣y(t)∣≤My​<∞⇒∣y[t]∣≤My​<∞​

Otherwise, the system is unstable, e.g. ∣y(t)∣→∞|y(t)|\rightarrow\infty∣y(t)∣→∞ as t→∞t\rightarrow\inftyt→∞ even when x(t)x(t)x(t) is bounded.

Note that time should be the independent variable, not the input.

Linear vs Nonlinear Systems

Linearity conditions:

  • Additive Property: {x1→y1x2→y2⟹x1+x2→y1+y2\begin{cases}x_1\rightarrow y_1\\x_2\rightarrow y_2\end{cases}\Longrightarrow x_1+x_2\rightarrow y_1+y_2{x1​→y1​x2​→y2​​⟹x1​+x2​→y1​+y2​
  • Scaling Property: x→y⇒kx→kyx\rightarrow y\Rightarrow kx\rightarrow kyx→y⇒kx→ky
  • Superposition combines the additive and scaling properties.

Nonlinear Systems do not comply with one or boths of the properties.

Importance of impulse response of linear systems: Let an arbitrary input x(t)=a1x1(t)+a2x2(t)+⋯+amxm(t)x(t)=a_1x_1(t)+a_2x_2(t)+\cdots+a_mx_m(t)x(t)=a1​x1​(t)+a2​x2​(t)+⋯+am​xm​(t). For a linear system the response should be y(t)=a1y1(t)+a2y2(t)+⋯+amym(t)y(t)=a_1y_1(t)+a_2y_2(t)+\cdots +a_my_m(t)y(t)=a1​y1​(t)+a2​y2​(t)+⋯+am​ym​(t).

We can approximate x(t)x(t)x(t) as a sum of rectangular pulses. The approximation improves as Δt→0\Delta t\rightarrow 0Δt→0 (impulse). So if we know the impulse response of a linear time invariant (LTI) system, we know its response to any input.

Impulse Response and Convolution

Impulse Response of Linear Systems

Given an arbitrary input:

x(t)=a1x1(t)+a2x2(t)+⋯+amxm(t)x(t)=a_1 x_1(t) + a_2 x_2(t)+\cdots + a_m x_m(t) x(t)=a1​x1​(t)+a2​x2​(t)+⋯+am​xm​(t)

For a linear system:

y(t)=a1y1(t)+a2y2(t)+⋯+amym(t)y(t) = a_1 y_1(t) + a_2 y_2(t) + \cdots + a_m y_m(t) y(t)=a1​y1​(t)+a2​y2​(t)+⋯+am​ym​(t)

x[n]=∑m=−∞∞x[m]δ[n−m]x[n]=\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty x[m]\delta[n-m] x[n]=m=−∞∑∞​x[m]δ[n−m]

Convolution Sum

Consider the following LTI system:

x[n]⇒y[n]x[n]\Rightarrow y[n] x[n]⇒y[n]

If x[n]=δ[n]x[n]=\delta[n]x[n]=δ[n], we call the impulse response of the system h[n]h[n]h[n].

δ[n]⇒h[n]δ[n−m]⇒h[n−m]\delta[n]\Rightarrow h[n]\qquad\qquad \delta[n-m]\Rightarrow h[n-m] δ[n]⇒h[n]δ[n−m]⇒h[n−m]

x[m]δ[n−m]⇒x[m]h[n−m](scaling)x[m]\delta[n-m]\Rightarrow x[m] h[n-m]\qquad\textrm{(scaling)} x[m]δ[n−m]⇒x[m]h[n−m](scaling)

∑m=−∞∞x[m]δ[n−m]⇒∑m=−∞∞x[m]h[n−m]\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty x[m]\delta[n-m] \Rightarrow \sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty x[m] h[n-m] m=−∞∑∞​x[m]δ[n−m]⇒m=−∞∑∞​x[m]h[n−m]

The Convolution sum of x[n]x[n]x[n] and h[n]h[n]h[n] is

y[n]=∑m=−∞∞x[m] h[n−m]=x[n]∗h[n]y[n]=\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty x[m]\ h[n-m]=x[n]*h[n] y[n]=m=−∞∑∞​x[m] h[n−m]=x[n]∗h[n]

Sliding Tape Algorithm

The step one should take to find the convolution sum:

  1. Time reverse h[m]⟶h[−m]h[m]\longrightarrow h[-m]h[m]⟶h[−m]
  2. Shift h[−m]h[-m]h[−m] by nnn units ⟶h[n−m]\longrightarrow h[n-m]⟶h[n−m]
  3. For shifts of n∈(−∞,∞)n\in(-\infty,\infty)n∈(−∞,∞):
    • Multiply x[m]x[m]x[m] and h[n−m]h[n-m]h[n−m] sample by sample
    • Add all the products and put the result in y[n]y[n]y[n]

Example: find output of the system with impulse response h[n]=(34)nu[n]\displaystyle h[n]=\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^n u[n]h[n]=(43​)nu[n] at time n=5n=5n=5 when x[n]=u[n]x[n]=u[n]x[n]=u[n].

y[n]=x[n]∗h[n]=∑m=−∞∞x[m] h[n−m]y[n]=x[n]*h[n]=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} x[m]\ h[n-m] y[n]=x[n]∗h[n]=m=−∞∑∞​x[m] h[n−m]

h[n−m]=u[n−m](34)n−m={(34)n−mn≥m0n<mh[n-m]=u[n-m]\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{n-m}= \begin{cases} \displaystyle \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{n-m} & n\ge m\\ \quad0& n<m \end{cases} h[n−m]=u[n−m](43​)n−m=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​(43​)n−m0​n≥mn<m​

y[5]=∑m=−∞∞x[m] h[5−m]=∑m=05(34)5−m=[(34)5]∑m=05(43)my[5] =\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty x[m]\ h[5-m]=\sum_{m=0}^5 \left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^{5-m}=\left[\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)^5\right]\sum_{m=0}^5 \left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^m y[5]=m=−∞∑∞​x[m] h[5−m]=m=0∑5​(43​)5−m=[(43​)5]m=0∑5​(34​)m

Convolution Integral

x(t)=∫−∞∞x(τ)δ(t−τ) dτx(t)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(\tau)\delta(t-\tau)\ d\tau x(t)=∫−∞∞​x(τ)δ(t−τ) dτ

Given the response of a Dirac impulse:

δ(t)⟹h(t)\delta(t)\Longrightarrow h(t) δ(t)⟹h(t)

∫−∞∞x(τ)δ(t−τ) dτ⟹∫−∞∞x(τ)h(t−τ) dτ\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(\tau)\delta(t-\tau)\ d\tau\Longrightarrow \int_{-\infty}^\infty x(\tau)h(t-\tau)\ d\tau∫−∞∞​x(τ)δ(t−τ) dτ⟹∫−∞∞​x(τ)h(t−τ) dτ

y(t)=x(t)∗h(t)=∫−∞∞x(τ)h(t−τ) dTy(t)=x(t)*h(t)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(\tau)h(t-\tau)\ d\Tau y(t)=x(t)∗h(t)=∫−∞∞​x(τ)h(t−τ) dT

Convolution Properties

Property Explanation
Commutative Property x∗h=h∗xx*h=h*xx∗h=h∗x
Distributive Property x∗(h+g)=x∗h+x∗gx*(h+g)=x*h+x*gx∗(h+g)=x∗h+x∗g
Assosiative Property x∗(h∗g)=(x∗h)∗gx*(h*g)=(x*h)*gx∗(h∗g)=(x∗h)∗g

Lastly, shift property:

  • Given x(t)∗h(t)=y(t)x(t)*h(t)=y(t)x(t)∗h(t)=y(t): y(t−T)=x(t)∗h(t−T)=x(t−T)∗h(t)y(t-T)=x(t)*h(t-T)=x(t-T)*h(t)y(t−T)=x(t)∗h(t−T)=x(t−T)∗h(t)
  • Given x[n]∗δ[n]=x[n]x[n]*\delta[n]=x[n]x[n]∗δ[n]=x[n]: x[n]∗δ[n−n0]=x[n−n0]x[n]*\delta[n-n_0]=x[n-n_0]x[n]∗δ[n−n0​]=x[n−n0​]

Deducing System Properties from Impulse Response

A. Memory

A system has memory if ∃t≠0:{h(t)≠0h[n]≠0\exists t\neq 0 :\begin{cases}h(t)\neq 0\\h[n]\neq 0\end{cases}∃t​=0:{h(t)​=0h[n]​=0​

A system is memoryless if {h(t)=Cδ(t)h[n]=Cδ[n]\begin{cases}h(t)=C\delta(t)\\h[n]=C\delta[n]\end{cases}{h(t)=Cδ(t)h[n]=Cδ[n]​

B. Causality

A system is causal if {h(t)=0h[n]=0∀t<0\begin{cases}h(t)=0\\h[n]=0\end{cases}\quad \forall t<0{h(t)=0h[n]=0​∀t<0

C. Stability

The output is bounded if {∫−∞∞∣h(τ)∣dτ∑n=−∞∞∣h[n]∣\begin{cases}\int_{-\infty}^\infty |h(\tau)|d\tau\\\sum_{n={-\infty}}^\infty|h[n]|\end{cases}{∫−∞∞​∣h(τ)∣dτ∑n=−∞∞​∣h[n]∣​ is bounded.

Total Response

A system's output is the result of two independent causes:

  • Zero-Input Response: output due to initial condition at t=0t=0t=0
  • Zero State Response: output due to input x(t)x(t)x(t) for t≥0t\ge 0t≥0, wehn initial condition is assumed to be zero.

Total Response=Zero-Input Response+Zero State Response\textrm{Total Response}=\textrm{Zero-Input Response} + \textrm{Zero State Response} Total Response=Zero-Input Response+Zero State Response

Find Unit Impulse Response Using Differential Equations

Consider the causal system below with zero initial conditions and find its unit impulse response.

y[n]−12y[n−1]=x[n]y[n]-\frac{1}{2}y[n-1]=x[n] y[n]−21​y[n−1]=x[n]

We have

x[n]=δ[n]⟹y[n]=h[n]x[n]=\delta[n]\Longrightarrow y[n]=h[n] x[n]=δ[n]⟹y[n]=h[n]

It may be more intuitive to rearrange the equation to

y[n]=x[n]+12y[n−1]y[n]=x[n]+\frac{1}{2}y[n-1] y[n]=x[n]+21​y[n−1]

Alas, we have

h[0]=1,h[1]=1/2,h[2]=1/4 ⋯→h[n]=1/2nh[0]=1,h[1]=1/2,h[2]=1/4\ \dots \rightarrow h[n]=1/2^n h[0]=1,h[1]=1/2,h[2]=1/4 ⋯→h[n]=1/2n

Laplace Transform and Z Transform

Laplace Transform for Continuous System

We want to find response of an LTI system with impulse response h(t)h(t)h(t) to input signal x(t)=estx(t)=e^{st}x(t)=est

y(t)=h(t)∗x(t)=∫−∞∞h(τ)x(t−τ) dτ=∫−∞∞h(τ)est e−sτ dτ=est∫−∞∞h(τ) e−sτ dτ=x(t)⋅H(s)\begin{aligned} y(t)&=h(t)*x(t)\\ &=\int^\infty_{-\infty} h(\tau) x(t-\tau)\ d\tau\\ &=\int^\infty_{-\infty} h(\tau) e^{st}\ e^{-s\tau}\ d\tau\\ &=e^{st} \int^\infty_{-\infty}h(\tau) \ e^{-s\tau}\ d\tau\\ &= x(t)\cdot H(s) \end{aligned} y(t)​=h(t)∗x(t)=∫−∞∞​h(τ)x(t−τ) dτ=∫−∞∞​h(τ)est e−sτ dτ=est∫−∞∞​h(τ) e−sτ dτ=x(t)⋅H(s)​

H(s)=∫−∞∞h(τ) e−sτ dτH(s)=\int^\infty_{-\infty}h(\tau) \ e^{-s\tau}\ d\tau H(s)=∫−∞∞​h(τ) e−sτ dτ

is the Laplace transform of h(t)h(t)h(t).

For a given sss, H(s)H(s)H(s) is constant, i.e. the output is input multiplied by a constant. Since the input este^{st}est pass through the system and appears in the output, it is called an eigenfunction of the system characteristic function.

No other function has this property:

H(s)=y(t)x(t)∣x(t)=est(=outputinput)H(s)=\left.\frac{y(t)}{x(t)}\right|_{x(t)=e^{st}}\qquad \left(=\frac{\textrm{output}}{\textrm{input}}\right) H(s)=x(t)y(t)​∣∣∣∣​x(t)=est​(=inputoutput​)

Laplace transform of an arbitrary function x(t)x(t)x(t) is

L[x(t)]=∫−∞∞x(t)e−st\mathscr{L}[x(t)]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-st} L[x(t)]=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−st

Z Transform for Discrete Systems

Now, we define ζ=es\zeta = e^sζ=es such that ζt=est\zeta^t=e^{st}ζt=est, we have

ζ=es=eσ+jω=eσejω∣ζ∣=∣eσ∣(∵∣ejω∣=cos⁡2ω+sin⁡2ω=1)\begin{aligned} \zeta &= e^s =e^{\sigma + j\omega}=e^\sigma e^{j\omega}\\ |\zeta| &=|e^\sigma|\qquad(\because |e^{j\omega}|=\sqrt{\cos^2\omega + \sin^2 \omega} = 1) \end{aligned} ζ∣ζ∣​=es=eσ+jω=eσejω=∣eσ∣(∵∣ejω∣=cos2ω+sin2ω​=1)​

Response of an LTI system h[n]h[n]h[n] to the complex exponential ζn\zeta^nζn is

y[n]=h[n]∗ζn=∑m=−∞∞h[m]ζn−m=ζn∑m=−∞∞h[m]ζ−my[n]=ζnH[ζ]\begin{aligned} y[n]&=h[n]*\zeta^n\\ &=\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty h[m] \zeta^{n-m}\\ &=\zeta^{n} \sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty h[m] \zeta^{-m}\\ y[n]&=\zeta^n H[\zeta]\qquad \end{aligned} y[n]y[n]​=h[n]∗ζn=m=−∞∑∞​h[m]ζn−m=ζnm=−∞∑∞​h[m]ζ−m=ζnH[ζ]​

H[ζ]=∑m=−∞∞h[m]ζ−mH[\zeta]=\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty h[m]\zeta^{-m} H[ζ]=m=−∞∑∞​h[m]ζ−m

is the Z transform of h[n]h[n]h[n].

H[ζ]=y[n]x[n]∣x[n]=ζn(=outputinput)H[\zeta]=\left.\frac{y[n]}{x[n]}\right|_{x[n]=\zeta^n} \qquad \left(=\frac{\textrm{output}}{\textrm{input}}\right) H[ζ]=x[n]y[n]​∣∣∣∣​x[n]=ζn​(=inputoutput​)

Z transform of an impulse response h(t)h(t)h(t) is denoted

H[ζ]=Z{h[n]}=∑n=−∞∞h[n]ζ−nH[\zeta]=\mathscr{Z}\{h[n]\}=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty h[n]\zeta^{-n} H[ζ]=Z{h[n]}=n=−∞∑∞​h[n]ζ−n

Z transform of an arbitrary signed x[n]x[n]x[n] is

X[ζ]=Z{x[n]}=∑−∞∞x[n]ζ−nX[\zeta]=\mathscr{Z}\{x[n]\}=\sum_{-\infty}^\infty x[n] \zeta^{-n} X[ζ]=Z{x[n]}=−∞∑∞​x[n]ζ−n

Poles and Zeros

H(s){has a pole at s=a if ∣H(a)∣=∞has a zero at s=b if ∣H(b)∣=0H(s) \begin{cases} \textrm{has a pole at } s=a \textrm{ if }|H(a)|=\infty\\ \textrm{has a zero at } s=b \textrm{ if }|H(b)|=0 \end{cases} H(s){has a pole at s=a if ∣H(a)∣=∞has a zero at s=b if ∣H(b)∣=0​

H[ζ]{has a pole at ζ=a if ∣H[a]∣=∞has a zero at ζ=b if ∣H[b]∣=0H[\zeta] \begin{cases} \textrm{has a pole at } \zeta=a \textrm{ if }|H[a]|=\infty\\ \textrm{has a zero at } \zeta=b \textrm{ if }|H[b]|=0 \end{cases} H[ζ]{has a pole at ζ=a if ∣H[a]∣=∞has a zero at ζ=b if ∣H[b]∣=0​

  • Poles are denoted x
  • Zeroes are denoted ∘\circ∘

Region of Convergence (ROC)

The ROC is the region of complex plane (sss or zzz-plane) for which the L\mathscr{L}L or Z\mathscr{Z}Z converges.

Example: let h(t)=e−at u(t)h(t)=e^{-at}\ u(t)h(t)=e−at u(t), we have

H(s)=∫−∞∞h(t) e−stdt=−1s+a(lim⁡t→∞e−(s+a)t−1)\begin{aligned} H(s)&=\int_{-\infty}^\infty h(t)\ e^{-st} dt\\ &=-\frac{1}{s+a}\left( \lim_{t\rightarrow \infty} e^{-(s+a)t}-1\right) \end{aligned} H(s)​=∫−∞∞​h(t) e−stdt=−s+a1​(t→∞lim​e−(s+a)t−1)​

We observe an interesting phenomenon

lim⁡t→∞e−(s+a)t={0ifRe{−(s+a)}<0∞ifRe{−(s+a)}>0\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty} e^{-(s+a)t} = \begin{cases} 0& \textrm{if}\quad\mathrm{Re}\{-(s+a)\} < 0\\ \infty& \textrm{if}\quad\mathrm{Re}\{-(s+a)\} > 0 \end{cases} t→∞lim​e−(s+a)t={0∞​ifRe{−(s+a)}<0ifRe{−(s+a)}>0​

The condition for convergence - Re{s}>−a\mathrm{Re}\{s\} > -aRe{s}>−a is the ROC.

{Zero: s=∞Pole: s=−a\begin{cases} \textrm{Zero: }s=\infty\\ \textrm{Pole: }s=-a \end{cases} {Zero: s=∞Pole: s=−a​

Similarly, for a discrete system, we let h[n]=anu[n]h[n]=a^n u[n]h[n]=anu[n]

H[ζ]=∑n=−∞∞h[n]ζ−n=∑n=−∞∞anζ−n=∑n=0∞(aζ)n\begin{aligned} H[\zeta]&=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty h[n]\zeta ^{-n}\\ &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty a^n \zeta^{-n}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^\infty \left(\frac{a}{\zeta}\right)^n \end{aligned} H[ζ]​=n=−∞∑∞​h[n]ζ−n=n=−∞∑∞​anζ−n=n=0∑∞​(ζa​)n​

We have

H[ζ]=11−aζROC: ∣ζ∣>∣a∣H[\zeta]=\frac{1}{\displaystyle 1-\frac{a}{\zeta}}\qquad \textrm{ROC:}\ |\zeta|>|a| H[ζ]=1−ζa​1​ROC: ∣ζ∣>∣a∣

{Zero: ζ=0Pole: ζ=a\begin{cases} \textrm{Zero: }\zeta=0\\ \textrm{Pole: }\zeta=a \end{cases} {Zero: ζ=0Pole: ζ=a​

Graphical summary of ROCs:

Note that Laplace an Z transform may have identical expression but very different ROC. So both algebraic description and ROC should be considered.

  • Roots of denominator are poles (x)

Motivation: Finding Response of A System

x(t)→h(t)  (impulse response)→y(t)=x(t)∗h(t)X(s)→H(s) (transfer function)→Y(s)=X(s)H(s)\begin{aligned} x(t)&\rightarrow h(t)\ \ \textrm{(impulse response)} &\rightarrow y(t)=x(t)*h(t)\\ X(s)&\rightarrow H(s)\ \textrm{(transfer function)} &\rightarrow Y(s)=X(s)H(s) \end{aligned} x(t)X(s)​→h(t)  (impulse response)→H(s) (transfer function)​→y(t)=x(t)∗h(t)→Y(s)=X(s)H(s)​

Procedure:

  1. Find X(s),H(s)X(s), H(s)X(s),H(s)
  2. Solve for y(s)=L−1{X(s)H(s)}y(s)=\mathscr{L}^{-1}\{X(s)H(s)\}y(s)=L−1{X(s)H(s)}

Solving Difference Equations with Z Transform

We aim to find the impulse response h[n]h[n]h[n] of the difference equation:

∑i=0Nai y[n−i]=∑j=0Mbj x[n−j]\sum_{i=0}^N a_i\ y[n-i] = \sum_{j=0}^M b_j\ x[n-j] i=0∑N​ai​ y[n−i]=j=0∑M​bj​ x[n−j]

We simply Z transform both sides, rearrange and derive H[ζ]=Y[ζ]X[ζ]\displaystyle H[\zeta]=\frac{Y[\zeta]}{X[\zeta]}H[ζ]=X[ζ]Y[ζ]​

{Z{y[n−i]}=ζ−iy[ζ]Z{x[n−j]}=ζ−jx[ζ]\begin{cases} \mathscr{Z}\{ y[n-i] \} = \zeta^{-i} y[\zeta]\\ \mathscr{Z}\{ x[n-j] \} = \zeta^{-j} x[\zeta] \end{cases} {Z{y[n−i]}=ζ−iy[ζ]Z{x[n−j]}=ζ−jx[ζ]​

Example: find impulse response h[n]h[n]h[n] of

y[n]−12y[n−1]=x[n]+13x[n−1](1−12ζ−1)Y[ζ]=(1+13ζ−1)X[ζ]H[ζ]=Y[ζ]X[ζ]=ζ+1/3ζ−1/2h[n]=(1/2)nu[n]+(1/3)(1/2)n−1u[n−1]\begin{aligned} y[n]-\frac{1}{2} y[n-1] &= x[n] + \frac{1}{3} x[n-1]\\ \left(1-\frac{1}{2}\zeta^{-1}\right) Y[\zeta]&= \left( 1 + \frac{1}{3} \zeta^{-1}\right) X[\zeta]\\ H[\zeta] &=\frac{Y[\zeta]}{X[\zeta]} = \frac{\zeta + 1/3}{\zeta - 1/2}\\ h[n] &= (1/2)^n u[n] + (1/3)(1/2)^{n-1} u[n-1] \end{aligned} y[n]−21​y[n−1](1−21​ζ−1)Y[ζ]H[ζ]h[n]​=x[n]+31​x[n−1]=(1+31​ζ−1)X[ζ]=X[ζ]Y[ζ]​=ζ−1/2ζ+1/3​=(1/2)nu[n]+(1/3)(1/2)n−1u[n−1]​

Freqeuncy Response and Filter Design

If we evaluate H(s)H(s)H(s) for s=jωs=j\omegas=jω (real component σ=0\sigma = 0σ=0) along the imaginary axis. We have

  • The frequency response H(jω)H(j\omega)H(jω)
  • The magnitude response ∣H(jω)|H(j\omega)∣H(jω)
  • The phase response ∠H(jω)\angle H(j\omega)∠H(jω)

related via

H(jω)=∣H(jω)∣ej∠H(jω)H(j\omega)= |H(j\omega)| e^{j\angle H(j\omega)} H(jω)=∣H(jω)∣ej∠H(jω)

Recall that if we have a system with impulse response h(t)h(t)h(t), and if the input signal is x(t)=estx(t)=e^{st}x(t)=est, we obtain y(t)=H(s)esty(t)=H(s)e^{st}y(t)=H(s)est. Since s=jωs=j\omegas=jω:

y(t)=H(jω)ejωt=∣H(jω)∣ej[ωt+∠H(jω)]\begin{aligned} y(t)&= H(j\omega) e^{j\omega t}\\ &=|H(j\omega)| e^{j[\omega t + \angle H(j\omega)]} \end{aligned} y(t)​=H(jω)ejωt=∣H(jω)∣ej[ωt+∠H(jω)]​

  • output frequency=input frequency\textrm{output frequency} = \textrm{input frequency}output frequency=input frequency
  • output magnitude=input magnitude×magnitude response ∣H(jω)∣\textrm{output magnitude} = \textrm{input magnitude} \times \textrm{magnitude response } |H(j\omega)|output magnitude=input magnitude×magnitude response ∣H(jω)∣
  • output phase=input phase+phase response\textrm{output phase} = \textrm{input phase} + \textrm{phase response}output phase=input phase+phase response

Quick example: Find freqeuncy response of the filter H(s)=11+s\displaystyle H(s)=\frac{1}{1+s}H(s)=1+s1​.

{∣H(jω)∣=∣11+jω∣=∣1∣∣1+jω∣=11+ω2∠H(jω)=∠1∠(1+jω)=0−arctan⁡(ω)=−arctan⁡(ω)\begin{cases} \displaystyle |H(j\omega)|=\left|\frac{1}{1+j\omega}\right| = \frac{|1|}{|1+j\omega|}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2}}\\ \displaystyle \angle H(j\omega) = \frac{\angle 1}{\angle(1+j\omega)}=0 - \arctan(\omega)=-\arctan(\omega) \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​∣H(jω)∣=∣∣∣∣​1+jω1​∣∣∣∣​=∣1+jω∣∣1∣​=1+ω2​1​∠H(jω)=∠(1+jω)∠1​=0−arctan(ω)=−arctan(ω)​

CT Transfer Function

H(s)=∑i=0maisi∑k=0nbksk=K∏i=1m(s−αi)∏k=1n(s−λk)H(s) =\frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=0}^m a_i s^i}{\displaystyle \sum_{k=0}^n b_k s^k} =K\frac{\displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^m (s-\alpha_i)}{\displaystyle \prod_{k=1}^n (s-\lambda_k)} H(s)=k=0∑n​bk​ski=0∑m​ai​si​=Kk=1∏n​(s−λk​)i=1∏m​(s−αi​)​

  • αi\alpha_iαi​ denotes zeroes
  • λk\lambda_kλk​ denotes poles

We have

{∣H(jω)∣=K∏i=1m∣jω−αi∣∏k=1n∣jω−λk∣∠H(jω)=∑i=1m∠(jω−αi)−∑k=1n∠(jω−λk)\begin{cases} |H(j\omega)| = K\frac{\displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^m |j\omega-\alpha_i|}{\displaystyle \prod_{k=1}^n |j\omega -\lambda_k|}\\ \displaystyle \angle H(j\omega) = \sum_{i=1}^m\angle (j\omega -\alpha_i) - \sum_{k=1}^n\angle (j\omega -\lambda_k) \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​∣H(jω)∣=Kk=1∏n​∣jω−λk​∣i=1∏m​∣jω−αi​∣​∠H(jω)=i=1∑m​∠(jω−αi​)−k=1∑n​∠(jω−λk​)​

CT Complex Pole Graphical Interpretation

If we have a complex pole λk=σk\lambda_k=\sigma_kλk​=σk​ we have a denominator fraction

jω−λk=−σk+j(ω−ωk)j\omega - \lambda_k = -\sigma_k + j(\omega - \omega_k) jω−λk​=−σk​+j(ω−ωk​)

Which we can use to interpret the vector jω−λkj\omega - \lambda_kjω−λk​ graphically:

We make the following observations:

  • The length from the pole to the complex frequency jωj\omegajω is jω−λkj\omega - \lambda_kjω−λk​. The greater the length, the less the gain.
  • If the pole is a real number kkk, then at ω=k\omega=kω=k, the length jω−λkj\omega - \lambda_kjω−λk​ is 2k\sqrt{2}k2​k, which means 3 dB reduction in gain.
  • If the complex component of the pole is much greater than the real component of the pole, then the product of the two lengths jω−λ1j\omega - \lambda_1jω−λ1​, jω−λ1j\omega - \lambda_1jω−λ1​ would be much smaller than when ω=0\omega=0ω=0. Thus we have a resonant peak. Think about why.

CT Non-Ideal Low-Pass Filter

First order low-pass filter SUCKS.

To enhance gain from 000 to ωc\omega_cωc​, we need to place poles at all frequencies in this band [0,ωc][0, \omega_c][0,ωc​]. We will need a continuous wall of poles to make an ideal low-pass filter.

A maximally flat frequency response in the pass band can be achieved with:

  • Butterworth filter: semicircle wall with infinite number of poles.
  • Chebyshev filter: the wall is a semi-ellipse.
Butterworth Chebyshev
Superior in passband Superior in Stopband (sharper drop)

DT Transfer Function

Consider the transfer function H[ζ]H[\zeta]H[ζ] for ζ=ejΩ\zeta=e^{j\Omega}ζ=ejΩ:

H[ejΩ]H\left[e^{j\Omega}\right] H[ejΩ]

What are those? recall

est=esnT=ejωnT=ejnΩ=ζn(ωT=Ω)e^{st}=e^{snT}=e^{j\omega nT} = e^{jn\Omega} = \zeta^n \qquad(\omega T = \Omega)est=esnT=ejωnT=ejnΩ=ζn(ωT=Ω)

  • In C.T. ω∈[0,∞)\omega\in [0, \infty)ω∈[0,∞)
  • In D.T. Ω∈[−π,π]\Omega\in [-\pi, \pi]Ω∈[−π,π]

To find the frequency response of a DT system given y[n]y[n]y[n] with respect to x[n]x[n]x[n] (direction relation without convolution):

  1. Z transform the equation that relates y[n]y[n]y[n] with x[n]x[n]x[n]
  2. Response is H[ζ]=Y[ζ]X[ζ]\displaystyle H[\zeta]=\frac{Y[\zeta]}{X[\zeta]}H[ζ]=X[ζ]Y[ζ]​

Example 1: find the frequency response of a filter y[n]=x[n−3]y[n]=x[n-3]y[n]=x[n−3].

Z{y[n]}=ζ−3Z{x[n]}Y[ζ]=ζ−3X[ζ]H[ζ]=Y[ζ]X[ζ]=ζ−3H[ejΩ]=e−jΩ3←ζ=ejΩ\begin{aligned} \mathscr{Z}\{y[n]\}&=\zeta^{-3} \mathscr{Z}\{x[n]\}\\ Y[\zeta] &= \zeta^{-3} X[\zeta]\\ H[\zeta] &=\displaystyle \frac{Y[\zeta]}{X[\zeta]} = \zeta^{-3}\\ H[e^{j\Omega}]&= e^{-j\Omega 3} \leftarrow \zeta=e^{j\Omega} \end{aligned} Z{y[n]}Y[ζ]H[ζ]H[ejΩ]​=ζ−3Z{x[n]}=ζ−3X[ζ]=X[ζ]Y[ζ]​=ζ−3=e−jΩ3←ζ=ejΩ​

{∣H(ejΩ)∣=1∠H(ejΩ)=−3Ω\begin{cases} |H(e^{j\Omega})| = 1\\ \angle H(e^{j\Omega}) = -3\Omega \end{cases} {∣H(ejΩ)∣=1∠H(ejΩ)=−3Ω​

Example 2:

For which sampling rate would this filter remove 60 Hz sinusoids?

ωT=Ω⇒ωT=π/2T is sampling interval2π60T=π/2⇒T=1/240⇒Fs=240Hz\begin{aligned} \omega T = \Omega &\Rightarrow \omega T = \pi / 2\qquad T\textrm{ is sampling interval}\\ 2\pi 60 T = \pi / 2 &\Rightarrow T= 1/240 \Rightarrow F_s = 240 Hz \end{aligned} ωT=Ω2π60T=π/2​⇒ωT=π/2T is sampling interval⇒T=1/240⇒Fs​=240Hz​

Finite Impulse Response (FIR) Filters

FIR for nonrecursive systems:

y[n]=∑k=0Mbkx[n−k]y[n]=\sum_{k=0}^M b_k x[n-k] y[n]=k=0∑M​bk​x[n−k]

Y[ζ]=(∑k=0Mbkζ−k) X[ζ]Y[\zeta]=\left(\sum_{k=0}^M b_k \zeta^{-k} \right)\ X[\zeta] Y[ζ]=(k=0∑M​bk​ζ−k) X[ζ]

H[ζ]=∑k=0Mbkζ−kH[\zeta] = \sum_{k=0}^M b_k \zeta^{-k} H[ζ]=k=0∑M​bk​ζ−k

Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) Filters

IIR for recursive systems:

∑i=0Naiy[n−i]=∑k=0Mbkx[n−k]\sum_{i=0}^N a_i y[n-i] = \sum_{k=0}^M b_k x[n-k] i=0∑N​ai​y[n−i]=k=0∑M​bk​x[n−k]

H[ζ]=∑k=0Mbkζ−k∑i=0Naiζ−iH[\zeta]=\frac{\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^M b_k \zeta^{-k}}{\displaystyle \sum_{i=0}^N a_i \zeta^{-i}} H[ζ]=i=0∑N​ai​ζ−ik=0∑M​bk​ζ−k​

Asymptotic Stability

To determine Asymptotic Stability aka Internal Stability of the system

H(s)=∑i=0Maisi∑k=0NbkskH(s)=\frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=0}^M a_i s^i}{\displaystyle \sum_{k=0}^N b_k s^k} H(s)=k=0∑N​bk​ski=0∑M​ai​si​

If M>NM>NM>N: the system is BIBO unstable: if the bounded input x(t)=u(t)x(t)=u(t)x(t)=u(t) is given, y(t)y(t)y(t) includes an impulse.

If M≤NM\le NM≤N and the numerator and denominator have no common factor (no pole-zero cancellation):

  1. The system is internally stable if and only if all poles of H(s)H(s)H(s) are in the left-half plane, i.e. all poles have negative real parts, Re{λi}<0Re\{\lambda_i\} < 0Re{λi​}<0.
  2. The system is unstable if and only if either or both of the following exist:
    • At least one pole of H(s)H(s)H(s) is in the RHP (Re{λi}>0Re\{\lambda_i\} > 0Re{λi​}>0)
    • There are repeated poles of H(s)H(s)H(s) on the imaginary axis.
  3. The system is marginally stable if there are unrepeated poles of H(s)H(s)H(s) on the imagineay axis.

Internal or Asymptotic Stability of DT Systems

If the numerator and denominator have no common factor (no pole-zero cancellation):

  • The system is internally stable if and only if all the poles of H[ζ]H[\zeta]H[ζ] are within the unit circle, i.e. ∣γi∣<1|\gamma_i| < 1∣γi​∣<1.
  • The system is unstable if and only if either
    • at least one pole is outside of the unit circle.
    • there are repeated poles on the unit circle.
  • The system is marginally stable if there are unrepeated poles on the unit circle, ∣γi∣=1|\gamma_i| = 1∣γi​∣=1 and no pole outside of the unit circle

For both CT and DT systems:

  • If a system is marginally stable or internally unstable, the system is BIBO unstable.
  • An asymptotically (internallY) stable system is BIBO stable.

Fourier Series

Consider periodic signal x(t)x(t)x(t) with period T0T_0T0​, x(t)=x(t+T0)x(t)=x(t+T_0)x(t)=x(t+T0​), we have the rule:

∫aa+T0x(t) dt=∫bb+T0x(t) dt\int_a^{a+T_0} x(t)\ dt = \int_b^{b+T_0} x(t)\ dt ∫aa+T0​​x(t) dt=∫bb+T0​​x(t) dt

with simplified notation

∫T0x(t) dtintegration over one period\int_{T_0} x(t)\ dt\qquad \textrm{integration over one period} ∫T0​​x(t) dtintegration over one period

The fundamental frequency f0=1/T0\displaystyle f_0 = 1/T_0f0​=1/T0​.

Fourier Series in Complex Exponential Form

x(t)=∑n=−∞∞Dnejnω0tx(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n e^{jn\omega_0 t} x(t)=n=−∞∑∞​Dn​ejnω0​t

where ω0=2πf0\omega_0 = 2\pi f_0ω0​=2πf0​.

A signal with period T0T_0T0​ can be described with superposition of infinite harmonics of exponentials with fundamental period of T0T_0T0​. (Harmonics are the integer multiples of fundamental frequency).

Orthogonal Property of Exponentials

Let ym=e−jmω0t,yn=ejnω0ty_m = e^{-j m \omega_0 t}, y_n = e^{j n \omega_0 t}ym​=e−jmω0​t,yn​=ejnω0​t, we have the Orthogonal Property of Exponentials:

∫0T0ymyn dt={0(n≠m)T0(n=m)\int_0^{T_0} y_m y_n\ dt = \begin{cases} 0 & (n\neq m)\\ T_0 & (n=m) \end{cases} ∫0T0​​ym​yn​ dt={0T0​​(n​=m)(n=m)​

Fourier Transform

∫T0x(t)e−jmω0t=DmT0\int_{T_0} x(t) e^{-jm\omega_0 t} = D_m T_0 ∫T0​​x(t)e−jmω0​t=Dm​T0​

The Fourier transform of function x(t)x(t)x(t) is

Dm=1T0∫T0x(t)e−jmω0t dtD_m = \frac{1}{T_0} \int_{T_0} x(t) e^{-jm\omega_0 t}\ dt Dm​=T0​1​∫T0​​x(t)e−jmω0​t dt

Because nnn and mmm are just arbitrary indices,

Dn=1T0∫T0x(t)e−jnω0t dtD_n = \frac{1}{T_0} \int_{T_0} x(t) e^{-jn\omega_0 t}\ dt Dn​=T0​1​∫T0​​x(t)e−jnω0​t dt

x(t)=∑n=−∞∞Dnejnω0tx(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n e^{jn\omega_0 t} x(t)=n=−∞∑∞​Dn​ejnω0​t

Note that for n=0n=0n=0 we get the DC term which is the time average of the signal:

D0=1T0∫T0x(t) dtD_0 = \frac{1}{T_0} \int_{T_0} x(t)\ dt D0​=T0​1​∫T0​​x(t) dt

If x(t)x(t)x(t) is real, then D−n=Dn∗D_{-n} = D_n^*D−n​=Dn∗​

Amplitude and Phase Spectra

DnD_nDn​ is a complex number Dn=∣Dn∣ej∠DnD_n = |D_n| e^{j\angle D_n}Dn​=∣Dn​∣ej∠Dn​

  • Amplitude Spectrum: plot of ∣Dn∣|D_n|∣Dn​∣ vs. ω(f)\omega(f)ω(f).
  • Phase Spectrum: plot of ∠Dn\angle D_n∠Dn​ vs. ω(f)\omega(f)ω(f).

For a real signal x(t)x(t)x(t): ∣D−n∣=∣Dn∣|D_{-n}| = |D_n|∣D−n​∣=∣Dn​∣ and ∠D−n=−∠Dn\angle D_{-n} = -\angle D_n∠D−n​=−∠Dn​

Spectra exist for both negative and positive frequency.

Example 1: x(t)=cos⁡ω0tx(t) = \cos \omega_0 tx(t)=cosω0​t

Since we know cos⁡ω0t=ejω0t+e−jω0t2\displaystyle \cos \omega_0 t = \frac{e^{j\omega_0 t} + e^{-j\omega_0 t}}{2}cosω0​t=2ejω0​t+e−jω0​t​.

x(t)=12ejω0t+12e−jω0t=∑n=−∞∞Dnejnω0t\begin{aligned} x(t) &= \frac{1}{2}e^{j\omega_0 t} + \frac{1}{2} e^{-j\omega_0 t}\\ &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n e^{jn\omega_0 t} \end{aligned} x(t)​=21​ejω0​t+21​e−jω0​t=n=−∞∑∞​Dn​ejnω0​t​

We obtain

{D1=1/2D−1=1/2Dn=0∀∣n∣≠1\begin{cases} D_1 = 1/2\\ D_{-1} = 1/2\\ D_n = 0 \forall |n| \neq 1 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​D1​=1/2D−1​=1/2Dn​=0∀∣n∣​=1​

Example 2:

x(t)x(t)x(t) is the following:

De find the DC term first:

D0=12π∫02πt2πdt=1/2D_0 = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{t}{2\pi} dt = 1/2 D0​=2π1​∫02π​2πt​dt=1/2

We then find the generic term:

Dn=12π∫02πt2πe−jn(1)t dt=14π2n2[1(j2π n+1)−1(1)]=j2πn\begin{aligned} D_n &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{t}{2\pi} e^{-j n(1) t}\ dt\\ &=\frac{1}{4\pi^2 n^2}[1(j2\pi\ n + 1) - 1(1)]\\ &=\frac{j}{2\pi n} \end{aligned} Dn​​=2π1​∫02π​2πt​e−jn(1)t dt=4π2n21​[1(j2π n+1)−1(1)]=2πnj​​

We have

{∣Dn∣=12πn∠Dn={π/2(n>0)−π/2(n<0)0(n=0)\begin{cases} \displaystyle |D_n| = \frac{1}{2\pi n}\\\\ \angle D_n = \begin{cases} \pi/2 & (n>0)\\ -\pi/2 & (n<0)\\ 0 & (n=0) \end{cases} \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​∣Dn​∣=2πn1​∠Dn​=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​π/2−π/20​(n>0)(n<0)(n=0)​​

Trigonometric Form

If x(t)x(t)x(t) is real.

x(t)=C0+∑n=1∞Cncos⁡(nω0t+θn)x(t) = C_0 +\sum_{n=1}^\infty C_n \cos (n\omega_0 t + \theta_n) x(t)=C0​+n=1∑∞​Cn​cos(nω0​t+θn​)

{C0=D0Cn=2∣Dn∣θn=∠Dn=−∠D−n\begin{cases} C_0 = D_0\\ C_n = 2 |D_n|\\ \theta_n = \angle D_n = -\angle D_{-n} \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​C0​=D0​Cn​=2∣Dn​∣θn​=∠Dn​=−∠D−n​​

Parseval's Theorem

Given a complex Fourier series

x(t)=∑n=−∞∞Dnejnω0tx(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n e^{jn\omega_0 t} x(t)=n=−∞∑∞​Dn​ejnω0​t

Power of the periodic signal is equal to the sum of the powers of its Fourier components.

Px=∑n=−∞∞∣Dn∣2P_x = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty |D_n|^2 Px​=n=−∞∑∞​∣Dn​∣2

Four a real signal:

Px=D02+2∑n=1∞∣Dn∣2P_x = D_0^2 + 2 \sum_{n=1}^\infty |D_n|^2 Px​=D02​+2n=1∑∞​∣Dn​∣2

Response of LTIC Systems to Periodic Inputs

Recall that let input x(t)=estx(t) = e^{st}x(t)=est, we have output y(t)=H(s)esty(t) = H(s) e^{st}y(t)=H(s)est where s=jω=jnω0s=j\omega = j n\omega_0s=jω=jnω0​.

est⟹H(s) estejnω0t⟹H(jnω0) ejnω0t∑n=−∞∞Dn ejnω0t⟹∑n=−∞∞Dn H(jnω0) ejnω0t\begin{aligned} e^{st}&\Longrightarrow H(s)\ e^{st}\\ e^{jn\omega_0 t}&\Longrightarrow H(jn\omega_0)\ e^{jn\omega_0 t}\\ \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n\ e^{jn\omega_0 t}&\Longrightarrow \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n\ H(jn\omega_0)\ e^{jn\omega_0 t} \end{aligned} estejnω0​tn=−∞∑∞​Dn​ ejnω0​t​⟹H(s) est⟹H(jnω0​) ejnω0​t⟹n=−∞∑∞​Dn​ H(jnω0​) ejnω0​t​

Fourier Transform for Aperiodic CT Signals

An aperiodic signal can be thought of as a periodic signal with a period of infinity blah blah blah.

xT0(t)=lim⁡T0→∞xT0(t)x_{T_0} (t) = \lim_{T_0\rightarrow \infty} x_{T_0}(t) xT0​​(t)=T0​→∞lim​xT0​​(t)

Dn=1T0∫−∞∞xT0(t)e−jnω0t dtD_n = \frac{1}{T_0} \int_{-\infty}^\infty x_{T_0}(t) e^{-jn\omega_0 t}\ dt Dn​=T0​1​∫−∞∞​xT0​​(t)e−jnω0​t dt

Let's define Fourier Transform X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω):

X(ω)=∫−∞∞x(t)e−jωt dtX(\omega)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-j\omega t}\ dt X(ω)=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−jωt dt

X(nω0)=∫−∞∞x(t)e−jnω0t dtX(n\omega_0)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-jn\omega_0 t}\ dt X(nω0​)=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−jnω0​t dt

This way,

Dn=1T0X(nω0)D_n = \frac{1}{T_0} X(n\omega_0) Dn​=T0​1​X(nω0​)

xT0(t)=∑n=−∞∞1T0X(nω0)ejnω0t=12π∑n=−∞∞ω0X(nω0)ejnω0t\begin{aligned} x_{T_0}(t) &= \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \frac{1}{T_0} X(n\omega_0) e^{jn\omega_0 t}\\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty \omega_0 X(n\omega_0) e^{jn\omega_0 t} \end{aligned} xT0​​(t)​=n=−∞∑∞​T0​1​X(nω0​)ejnω0​t=2π1​n=−∞∑∞​ω0​X(nω0​)ejnω0​t​

As T0→∞T_0 \rightarrow \inftyT0​→∞, ω0→0\omega_0 \rightarrow 0ω0​→0, we arrive at the Fourier Integral

x(t)=12π∫−∞∞X(ω)ejωt dωx(t) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\infty}^\infty X(\omega) e^{j\omega t}\ d\omega x(t)=2π1​∫−∞∞​X(ω)ejωt dω

Now, introducing Inverse Fourier Transform:

F{x(t)}≡X(ω)=∫−∞∞x(t)e−jωt dtF−1{X(ω)}≡x(t)=12π∫−∞∞X(ω)ejωt dω\begin{aligned} \mathcal{F\{x(t)\}}&\equiv X(\omega) =\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-j\omega t}\ dt\\ \mathcal{F}^{-1}\left\{ X(\omega)\right\}&\equiv x(t) =\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^\infty X(\omega) e^{j\omega t}\ d\omega \end{aligned} F{x(t)}F−1{X(ω)}​≡X(ω)=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−jωt dt≡x(t)=2π1​∫−∞∞​X(ω)ejωt dω​

Laplace Transform!

L{x(t)}≡X(s)=∫−∞∞x(t)e−st dt\mathcal{L}\left\{ x(t) \right\}\equiv X(s) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-st}\ dtL{x(t)}≡X(s)=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−st dt

Fourier transform is the special case of Laplace transform for s=jωs=j\omegas=jω when the ROC of X(s)X(s)X(s) includes the imaginary axis X(jω)=X(ω)X(j\omega) = X(\omega)X(jω)=X(ω); otherwise X(jω)≠X(ω)X(j\omega)\neq X(\omega)X(jω)​=X(ω).

Example: F{δ(t)}\mathcal{F}\{\delta (t)\}F{δ(t)}

X(ω)=∫−∞∞δ(t)e−jωt dt=1X(\omega) =\int_{-\infty}^\infty \delta(t) e^{-j\omega t}\ dt = 1 X(ω)=∫−∞∞​δ(t)e−jωt dt=1

Example: Find the inverse Fourier transform of δ(ω)\delta(\omega)δ(ω):

F−1{δ(ω)}=12π∫−∞∞δ(ω)ejωt dω=12π\mathcal{F}^{-1}\{\delta (\omega)\} =\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \delta(\omega) e^{j\omega t}\ d\omega = \frac{1}{2\pi} F−1{δ(ω)}=2π1​∫−∞∞​δ(ω)ejωt dω=2π1​

Example 2: find the Fourier transform of x(t)x(t)x(t)

X(ω)=∫−∞∞x(t)e−jωt dt=∫−aae−jωt dt=−1jω[e−jaω−ejaω]=2ωsin⁡(ωa)=2a sinc(ωa)\begin{aligned} X(\omega)&=\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-j\omega t}\ dt\\ &=\int_{-a}^a e^{-j\omega t}\ dt\\ &=-\frac{1}{j\omega}\left[e^{-ja\omega} - e^{ja\omega}\right]\\ &=\frac{2}{\omega} \sin(\omega a)\\ &= 2a\ \textrm{sinc}(\omega a) \end{aligned} X(ω)​=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−jωt dt=∫−aa​e−jωt dt=−jω1​[e−jaω−ejaω]=ω2​sin(ωa)=2a sinc(ωa)​

The sinc(x)\textrm{sinc}(x)sinc(x) function, also known as the sampling function is a function that arises frequently in signal processing and the theory of Fourier transforms. The full name of the function is sine cardinal.

sinc(x)={1for x=0sin⁡xxotherwise\textrm{sinc}(x)=\begin{cases} 1&\textrm{for }x=0\\ \displaystyle \frac{\sin x}{x}&\textrm{otherwise} \end{cases} sinc(x)=⎩⎨⎧​1xsinx​​for x=0otherwise​

Fourier Spectra

X(ω)=∣X(ω)∣ej∠X(ω)X(\omega) = |X(\omega) | e^{j\angle X(\omega)} X(ω)=∣X(ω)∣ej∠X(ω)

where

  • ∣X(ω)∣|X(\omega) |∣X(ω)∣ is the magnitude spectrum
  • ∠X(ω)\angle X(\omega)∠X(ω) is the phase spectrum

Example: x(t)=e−atu(t)x(t) = e^{-at} u(t)x(t)=e−atu(t)

x(ω)=∫−∞∞e−atu(t)e−jωt dt=∫0∞e−(a+jω)t dt=−1a+jωe−(a+jω)t∣0∞\begin{aligned} x(\omega) &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-at} u(t) e^{-j\omega t}\ dt\\ &= \int_0^\infty e^{-(a+j\omega)t}\ dt\\ &=\left.-\frac{1}{a+j\omega} e^{-(a+j\omega) t} \right|_0^\infty \end{aligned} x(ω)​=∫−∞∞​e−atu(t)e−jωt dt=∫0∞​e−(a+jω)t dt=−a+jω1​e−(a+jω)t∣∣∣∣​0∞​​

Fourier Transform only exists for a>0a>0a>0, in which case

X(ω)=1a+jω=a−jωa2+ω2X(\omega) = \frac{1}{a+j\omega} = \frac{a-j\omega}{a^2 + \omega^2} X(ω)=a+jω1​=a2+ω2a−jω​

{∣X(ω)∣=a2+ω2a2+ω2=1a2+ω2∠X(ω)=arctan⁡(−ω/a)\begin{cases} \displaystyle |X(\omega)| = \frac{\sqrt{a^2 + \omega^2}}{a^2 + \omega^2} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2 + \omega^2}} \\ \angle X(\omega) = \arctan(-\omega/a) \end{cases} ⎩⎨⎧​∣X(ω)∣=a2+ω2a2+ω2​​=a2+ω2​1​∠X(ω)=arctan(−ω/a)​

Fourier Series Case Study: Pulse Train with Period Ts

δTs(t)=∑n=−∞∞Dnejnωst\delta_{T_s}(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty D_n e^{jn\omega_s t} δTs​​(t)=n=−∞∑∞​Dn​ejnωs​t

Dn=1Ts∫−Ts/2Ts/2δTs(t)e−jnωst dt=1Ts∫−Ts/2Ts/2δ(t)e−jnωst dt=1Ts\begin{aligned} D_n &= \frac{1}{T_s} \int_{-T_s/2}^{T_s/2} \delta_{T_s}(t) e^{-jn\omega_s t}\ dt\\ &=\frac{1}{T_s} \int_{-T_s/2}^{T_s/2} \delta(t) e^{-jn\omega_s t}\ dt\\ &= \frac{1}{T_s} \end{aligned} Dn​​=Ts​1​∫−Ts​/2Ts​/2​δTs​​(t)e−jnωs​t dt=Ts​1​∫−Ts​/2Ts​/2​δ(t)e−jnωs​t dt=Ts​1​​

δTs(t)=1Ts∑n=−∞∞ejnωst\delta_{T_s}(t)=\frac{1}{T_s} \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty e^{jn\omega_s t} δTs​​(t)=Ts​1​n=−∞∑∞​ejnωs​t

In trigonometric form:

{C0=D0=1/TsCn=2∣Dn∣=2/Tsθn=∠Dn=arctan⁡(0)=0\begin{cases} C_0 = D_0 = 1/T_s\\ C_n = 2 |D_n| = 2/T_s\\ \theta_n = \angle D_n = \arctan(0) = 0 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​C0​=D0​=1/Ts​Cn​=2∣Dn​∣=2/Ts​θn​=∠Dn​=arctan(0)=0​

δTs=1Ts[1+2(cos(ωst)+cos⁡(2ωst)+cos⁡(3ωst)+⋯ )]\delta_{T_s} = \frac{1}{T_s} [1 + 2(cos(\omega_s t) + \cos(2\omega_s t) + \cos(3\omega_s t) + \cdots)] δTs​​=Ts​1​[1+2(cos(ωs​t)+cos(2ωs​t)+cos(3ωs​t)+⋯)]

Fourier Transform Properties

Time-Frequency Duality

Fourier transform and inverse Fourier transform are very similar with 2 differences:

  1. The factor of 1/2π1/2\pi1/2π
  2. The signs of complex exponential

x(t)=12π∫−∞∞X(ω)ejωtdωX(ω)=∫−∞∞x(t)e−jωt dtx(t) = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\infty}^\infty X(\omega) e^{j\omega t} d\omega\qquad X(\omega) =\int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t) e^{-j\omega t}\ dt x(t)=2π1​∫−∞∞​X(ω)ejωtdωX(ω)=∫−∞∞​x(t)e−jωt dt

x(t)⇔X(ω)X(t)⇔2πx(−ω)\begin{aligned} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega)\\ X(t) &\Leftrightarrow 2\pi x(-\omega) \end{aligned} x(t)X(t)​⇔X(ω)⇔2πx(−ω)​

What in space is going on? We know that

x(t)=12π∫−∞∞X(ω)ejωt dω2πx(−t)=∫−∞∞X(ω)e−jωtdω\begin{aligned} x(t) &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\infty}^\infty X(\omega) e^{j\omega t}\ d\omega\\ 2\pi x(-t) &= \int_{-\infty}^\infty X(\omega) e^{-j\omega t} d\omega \end{aligned} x(t)2πx(−t)​=2π1​∫−∞∞​X(ω)ejωt dω=∫−∞∞​X(ω)e−jωtdω​

Example:

δ(t)⇔112π⇔δ(ω)\begin{aligned} \delta(t) &\Leftrightarrow 1\\ \displaystyle \frac{1}{2\pi} &\Leftrightarrow \delta(\omega) \end{aligned} δ(t)2π1​​⇔1⇔δ(ω)​

Fourier Transform Linearity

a1x1(t)+a2x2(t)⇔a1X1(ω)+a2X2(ω)a_1 x_1(t) + a_2 x_2(t) \Leftrightarrow a_1 X_1(\omega) + a_2 X_2(\omega) a1​x1​(t)+a2​x2​(t)⇔a1​X1​(ω)+a2​X2​(ω)

Fourier Transform Scaling Property

x(t)⇔X(ω)x(at)⇔1∣a∣X(ω/a)\begin{aligned} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega)\\ x(at) &\Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{|a|} X(\omega / a) \end{aligned} x(t)x(at)​⇔X(ω)⇔∣a∣1​X(ω/a)​

Compression in time causes expansion in frequency, and vice versa. Take an extreme example:

  • Implication 1: wider x(t)x(t)x(t) causes narrower special bandwidth and vice versa.
  • Implication 2: if a=−1a=-1a=−1, x(−t)⇔X(−ω)x(-t) \Leftrightarrow X(-\omega)x(−t)⇔X(−ω). Time reversal causes frequency reversal.

Time-shifting Proeperty

x(t)⇔X(ω)x(t−t0)⇔X(ω)e−jωt0\begin{aligned} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega)\\ x(t-t_0) &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega) e^{-j\omega t_0} \end{aligned} x(t)x(t−t0​)​⇔X(ω)⇔X(ω)e−jωt0​​

Implication:

X(ω)=∣X(ω)∣ej∠X(ω)X(ω)e−jωt0=∣X(ω)∣ej[∠X(ω)−ωt0]\begin{aligned} X(\omega) &= |X(\omega)| e^{j\angle X(\omega)}\\ X(\omega) e^{-j\omega t_0} &= |X(\omega)| e^{j[\angle X(\omega) - \omega t_0]} \end{aligned} X(ω)X(ω)e−jωt0​​=∣X(ω)∣ej∠X(ω)=∣X(ω)∣ej[∠X(ω)−ωt0​]​

Note that ∣e−jωt0∣=1|e^{-j\omega t_0}| = 1∣e−jωt0​∣=1. Phase shifting with a slope of −t0-t_0−t0​ as a function of ω\omegaω caused by time shifting by t0t_0t0​.

Fourier Transform Frequency Shifting Property

x(t)⇔X(ω)x(t)ejω0t⇔X(ω−ω0)\begin{aligned} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega)\\ x(t) e^{j\omega_0 t} &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega - \omega_0) \end{aligned} x(t)x(t)ejω0​t​⇔X(ω)⇔X(ω−ω0​)​

x(t)⇔X(ω)x(t)\Leftrightarrow X(\omega) x(t)⇔X(ω)

Implication: Amplitude Modulation:

12x(t)[ejω0t+e−jω0t]⇔12X(ω−ω0)+X(ω+ω0)x(t)cos⁡(ω0t)⇔12[X(ω−ω0)+X(ω+ω0)]\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} x(t) \left[e^{j\omega_0 t} + e^{-j\omega_0 t} \right] &\Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{2} X(\omega - \omega_0) + X(\omega + \omega_0)\\ x(t) \cos(\omega_0 t) &\Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{2} [X(\omega-\omega_0) + X(\omega+\omega_0)] \end{aligned} 21​x(t)[ejω0​t+e−jω0​t]x(t)cos(ω0​t)​⇔21​X(ω−ω0​)+X(ω+ω0​)⇔21​[X(ω−ω0​)+X(ω+ω0​)]​

Multiplication of a signal x(t)x(t)x(t) by a sinusoid of frequency ω0\omega_0ω0​ shifts the spectrum of X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) by ±ω0\pm \omega_0±ω0​.

Fourier Transform Convolution

x1(t)∗x2(t)⇔X1(ω)X2(ω)(Time Convolution)2πx1(t)x2(t)⇔X1(ω)∗X2(ω)(Frequency Convolution)\begin{aligned} x_1(t) * x_2(t) &\Leftrightarrow X_1(\omega) X_2(\omega) &&\textrm{(Time Convolution)}\\ 2\pi x_1(t)x_2(t) &\Leftrightarrow X_1(\omega) * X_2(\omega) &&\textrm{(Frequency Convolution)} \end{aligned} x1​(t)∗x2​(t)2πx1​(t)x2​(t)​⇔X1​(ω)X2​(ω)⇔X1​(ω)∗X2​(ω)​​(Time Convolution)(Frequency Convolution)​

Fourier Transform Time Differentiation and Time Integration

x(t)⇔X(ω)ddtx(t)⇔jω X(ω)dndtnx(t)⇔(jω)nX(ω)∫−∞tx(τ) dτ⇔X(ω)jω+πX(0)δ(ω)\begin{aligned} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow X(\omega)\\ \frac{d}{dt} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow j\omega\ X(\omega)\\ \frac{d^n}{dt^n} x(t) &\Leftrightarrow (j\omega)^n X(\omega)\\ \int_{-\infty}^t x(\tau)\ d\tau &\Leftrightarrow \frac{X(\omega)}{j\omega} + \pi X(0) \delta (\omega) \end{aligned} x(t)dtd​x(t)dtndn​x(t)∫−∞t​x(τ) dτ​⇔X(ω)⇔jω X(ω)⇔(jω)nX(ω)⇔jωX(ω)​+πX(0)δ(ω)​

Case Study 1: Fourier Transform of Sign Function

Find the Fourier Transform of sign function sgn(t)\mathrm{sgn}(t)sgn(t) where

sgn(t)={1t≥0−1t<0\mathrm{sgn}(t)=\begin{cases} 1& t\ge 0\\ -1 & t<0 \end{cases} sgn(t)={1−1​t≥0t<0​

We note that

1+sgn(t)=2u(t)1+\textrm{sgn}(t) = 2 u(t) 1+sgn(t)=2u(t)

ddt(1+sgn(t))=2ddtu(t)ddtsgn(t)=2δ(t)jωF[sgn(t)]=2\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dt} (1+\mathrm{sgn}(t)) &= 2\frac{d}{dt} u(t)\\ \frac{d}{dt}\mathrm{sgn}(t) &= 2\delta(t)\\ j\omega \mathcal{F}[\mathrm{sgn}(t)]&=2 \end{aligned} dtd​(1+sgn(t))dtd​sgn(t)jωF[sgn(t)]​=2dtd​u(t)=2δ(t)=2​

Finally, we have

F[sgn(t)]=2jωF[\mathrm{sgn}(t)] = \frac{2}{j\omega} F[sgn(t)]=jω2​

Case Study 2: Fourier Transform of Step Function

Find the Fourier transform of u(t)u(t)u(t)

u(t)=12+12sgn(t)u(t) = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{sgn}(t) u(t)=21​+21​sgn(t)

F[u(t)]=F[12+12sgn(t)]\mathcal{F}[u(t)] = \mathcal{F}\left[\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{sgn}(t) \right] F[u(t)]=F[21​+21​sgn(t)]

Note that using duality, we know

F[δ(t)]=1⇔F[1]=2πδ(ω)\mathcal{F}[\delta(t)] = 1 \qquad\Leftrightarrow\qquad \mathcal{F}[1]=2\pi \delta(\omega) F[δ(t)]=1⇔F[1]=2πδ(ω)

As a result, we have

F[u(t)]=πδ(ω)+1jω\mathcal{F}[u(t)] =\pi \delta(\omega) + \frac{1}{j\omega} F[u(t)]=πδ(ω)+jω1​
